column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text="I han got no money, I tell ye," said Barton.
#Text=Wilson looked disappointed.
#Text=Barton tried not to be interested, but he could not help it in spite of his gruffness.
#Text=He rose, and went to the cupboard (his wife ' s pride long ago).
#Text=There lay the remains of his dinner, hastily put by ready for supper.
#Text=Bread, and a slice of cold fat boiled bacon.
#Text=He wrapped them in his handkerchief, put them in the crown of his hat, and said—"Come, let ' s be going."
#Text="Going—art thou going to work this time o '  day?"
#Text="No, stupid, to be sure not.
#Text=As they passed, women from their doors tossed household slops of every description into the gutter; they ran into the next pool, which overflowed and stagnated.
#Text=Heaps of ashes were the stepping-stones, on which the passer-by, who cared in the least for cleanliness, took care not to put his foot.

#Text=Our friends were not dainty, but even they picked their way till they got to some steps leading down into a small area, where a person standing would have his head about one foot below the level of the street, and might at the same time, without the least motion of his body, touch the window of the cellar and the damp muddy wall right opposite.
#Text=You went down one step even from the foul area into the cellar in which a family of human beings lived.
#Text=It was very dark inside.
#Text=The window-panes were, many of them, broken and stuffed with rags, which was reason enough for the dusky light that pervaded the place even at mid-day.

#Text=After the account I have given of the state of the street, no one can be surprised that on going into the cellar inhabited by Davenport, the smell was so fœtid as almost to knock the two men down.

#Text=Quickly recovering themselves, as those inured to such things do, they began to penetrate the thick darkness of the place, and to see three or four little children rolling on the damp, nay wet, brick floor, through which the stagnant, filthy moisture of the street oozed up; the fire-place was empty and black; the wife sat on her husband ' s lair, and cried in the dank loneliness.
#Text="See, missis, I ' m back again.
#Text="Yo stop here, and I ' ll be back in half-an-hour."
#Text=So he strode, and ran, and hurried home.
#Text=He emptied into the ever-useful pocket-handkerchief the little meal remaining in the mug.
#Text=Mary would have her tea at Miss Simmonds ' ; her food for the day was safe.
#Text=Then he went up-stairs for his better coat, and his one, gay, red-and-yellow silk pocket-handkerchief—his jewels, his plate, his valuables, these were.

#Text=He went to the pawn-shop; he pawned them for five shillings; he stopped not, nor stayed, till he was once more in London Road, within five minutes '  walk of Berry Street—then he loitered in his gait, in order to discover the shops he wanted.
#Text=He bought meat, and a loaf of bread, candles, chips, and from a little retail yard he purchased a couple of hundredweights of coals.
#Text=Some money yet remained—all destined for them, but he did not yet know how best to spend it.
#Text=Food, light, and warmth, he had instantly seen were necessary; for luxuries he would wait.
#Text=Wilson ' s eyes filled with tears when he saw Barton enter with his purchases.
#Text=He understood it all, and longed to be once more in work, that he might help in some of these material ways, without feeling that he was using his son ' s money.
#Text=But though "silver and gold he had none," he gave heart-service and love works of far more value.
#Text=Nor was John Barton behind in these.
#Text="The fever" was (as it usually is in Manchester) of a low, putrid, typhoid kind; brought on by miserable living, filthy neighbourhood, and great depression of mind and body.
#Text=It is virulent, malignant, and highly infectious.
#Text=But the poor are fatalists with regard to infection; and well for them it is so, for in their crowded dwellings no invalid can be isolated.
#Text=Wilson asked Barton if he thought he should catch it, and was laughed at for his idea.
#Text=The two men, rough, tender nurses as they were, lighted the fire, which smoked and puffed into the room as if it did not know the way up the damp, unused chimney.
#Text=The very smoke seemed purifying and healthy in the thick clammy air.

#Text=The children clamoured again for bread; but this time Barton took a piece first to the poor, helpless, hopeless woman, who still sat by the side of her husband, listening to his anxious miserable mutterings.
#Text=She took the bread, when it was put into her hand, and broke a bit, but could not eat.
#Text=She was past hunger.
#Text=She fell down on the floor with a heavy unresisting bang.
#Text=The men looked puzzled.
#Text="She ' s well-nigh clemmed," said Barton.
#Text="Folk do say one mustn ' t give clemmed people much to eat; but, bless us, she ' ll eat nought."
#Text="I ' ll tell yo what I ' ll do," said Wilson.
#Text="I ' ll take these two big lads, as does nought but fight, home to my missis ' s for to-night, and I ' ll get a jug o '  tea.
#Text=The Davenports paid threepence more for having two rooms.
#Text=When he turned round again, he saw the woman suckling the child from her dry, withered breast.
#Text="Surely the lad is weaned!"
#Text=exclaimed he, in surprise.
#Text="Why, how old is he?"
